channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Trump escalates pressure on Venezuelan drug trade. And, judge pauses shutdown layoffs
item.description: Trump escalates pressure on Venezuela by authorizing covert CIA operations. And, a federal judge halts the Trump administration's shutdown layoffs.
item.content:encoded:
Trump escalates pressure on Venezuela by authorizing covert CIA operations. And, a federal judge halts the Trump administration's shutdown layoffs.

(Image credit: Andrew Caballero-Reynolds)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: Targets of Trump's Justice Department must pay up, even if they win
item.description: For defendants facing criminal charges from the Justice Department, the costs of fighting are enormous and can reverberate for years, according to veteran attorneys.
item.content:encoded:
For defendants facing criminal charges from the Justice Department, the costs of fighting are enormous and can reverberate for years, according to veteran attorneys.

(Image credit: Andrew Harnik)
item.dc:creator: Carrie Johnson

item.title: 80-year-old grandmother becomes oldest woman to finish the Ironman World Championship
item.description: Just 20 years ago, Natalie Grabow was learning to swim. Now she's hailed as an inspiration after winning her age group at the famously grueling triathlon competition in Hawaii.
item.content:encoded:
Just 20 years ago, Natalie Grabow was learning to swim. Now she's hailed as an inspiration after winning her age group at the famously grueling triathlon competition in Hawaii.

(Image credit: Ezra Shaw)
item.dc:creator: Bill Chappell

item.title: 'Death fold' proteins can make cells self-destruct. Scientists want to control them
item.description: Scientists are hoping to treat diseases including cancer and Alzheimer's by influencing how cells make life-or-death decisions.
item.content:encoded:
Scientists are hoping to treat diseases including cancer and Alzheimer's by influencing how cells make life-or-death decisions.

(Image credit: faithiecannoise/iStockphoto)
item.dc:creator: Jon Hamilton

item.title: The two wildcards shaping the tail end of the Virginia race for governor
item.description: Virginia is just weeks away from electing a new governor, but the government shutdown and an explosive text message scandal in the race for attorney general could reshape the election.
item.content:encoded:
Virginia is just weeks away from electing a new governor, but the government shutdown and an explosive text message scandal in the race for attorney general could reshape the election.

(Image credit: Win McNamee)
item.dc:creator: Margaret Barthel

item.title: Should the bus be free? Transit advocates are divided
item.description: "Free buses" is one of the big ideas that helped Zohran Mamdani win the Democratic mayoral primary in New York City. But the track record in cities that have stopped collecting fares is mixed.
item.content:encoded:
"Free buses" is one of the big ideas that helped Zohran Mamdani win the Democratic mayoral primary in New York City. But the track record in cities that have stopped collecting fares is mixed.

(Image credit: Joel Rose)
item.dc:creator: Joel Rose

item.title: Health insurance premiums are going up next year — unless you work at these companies
item.description: As U.S. health insurance costs rise, some companies are paying for all of their workers' premiums. It's a big expense — but they say it pays off.
item.content:encoded:
As U.S. health insurance costs rise, some companies are paying for all of their workers' premiums. It's a big expense — but they say it pays off.

(Image credit: Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Maria Aspan

item.title: For private flood insurance companies, the government shutdown is good for business
item.description: With the government shutdown, the National Flood Insurance Program is no longer writing new policies. It's causing problems for would-be homeowners, but private companies have stepped in to help.
item.content:encoded:
With the government shutdown, the National Flood Insurance Program is no longer writing new policies. It's causing problems for would-be homeowners, but private companies have stepped in to help.

(Image credit: Kerry Sheridan)
item.dc:creator: Greg Allen

item.title: Trump confirms the CIA is conducting covert operations inside Venezuela
item.description: The acknowledgement of covert action in Venezuela comes after the U.S. military in recent weeks has carried out a series of deadly strikes against alleged drug-smuggling boats in the Caribbean.
item.content:encoded:
The acknowledgement of covert action in Venezuela comes after the U.S. military in recent weeks has carried out a series of deadly strikes against alleged drug-smuggling boats in the Caribbean.

(Image credit: John McDonnell)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Doctors Without Borders permanently closes its emergency center in Haiti's capital
item.description: Doctors Without Borders said Wednesday that ongoing violence in the capital of Haiti has forced it to permanently close its Port-au-Prince emergency care center, a city now 90% controlled by gangs.
item.content:encoded:
Doctors Without Borders said Wednesday that ongoing violence in the capital of Haiti has forced it to permanently close its Port-au-Prince emergency care center, a city now 90% controlled by gangs.

(Image credit: Odelyn Joseph)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
